comment.author: 37426109@N07
comment._content:
This image looks like it could be from the early 70's. The Carriage seats look much like the seats found in a Silver "Comeng" or "Gionian" set, the windows look a little different, they could have been changed later on to meet newer Australian standards. Clearly from the interior, there also seems to be fluorescent lights.

The photos appears to have possibly been taken whilst crossing the "Harbour Bridge", taking note of the fence outside the window on the right.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Thanks for your comment, Historically Sympathetic; it's very interesting. That moustache also looks quite 70s. I found this image of the fencing on the Sydney Harbour Bridge - it does look similar. I'm not sure if it's unique to the bridge, though?

comment.author: 27331537@N06
37426109@N07
comment._content: The image of the Harbour Bridge linked, is similar, but that is the pedestrian side, which of course was used for the tram line. The train side is adjacent to what is now the bicycle lane,  I'm also sure that the fence is this design, I travel over the bridge every day.

comment.author: 54505671@N06
comment._content: If it's from the early 70s, then the train is a Comeng, not a Goninan train.  Goninan started making similar carriages in the very late 70s.  The windows were a feature of Sydney train travel for several decades, and are called "Beclawat" windows, afer their manufacturer.  They replaced the old lift-up windows used in earler carriages (the single deck ones), and were themselves subsequently replaced by "hopper" windows (the ones where the top opens inwards a few centimetres).  All new trains are air-conditioned and have fully sealed windows. Cityrail has only existed since the early 90s, so the logo on the inspectors' caps would likely have been "Public Transport Commission of NSW"

comment.author: 54505671@N06
comment._content:
Aah, I could be wrong.  It might be 1979.

There were four NASA probes that did Jovian fly-bys in the 1970s. Closest approach to Jupiter was:
Pioneer 10 : 3rd December 1973
Pioneer 11 : 2nd December 1974
Voyager 1 :   5th March, 1979
Voyager 2 :   9th July, 1979

Voyager 2 discovered the first extraterrestrial volcanoes (on a moon of Jupiter), which may have been the "Strange Finds" of the headline, but more importantly, Voyager 2's fly-by was the only one to occur in the Australian winter, and the people on that train are all in long sleeves.  We're probably looking at July '79 here.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/theloadeddog] Thanks for this info about the railway carriages and windows. Going by your NASA dates we've added a c.1979 date to the photo.

AB
